overview: The purpose of this Act is to permanently establish the women's court program in the first circuit and establish a two-year women's court pilot program in the circuit court of the Kona division of the third circuit. [13] This measure also requires the judiciary to submit reports to the legislature regarding the pilot program for women's court. [13] Part III, which establishes the pilot program, shall be repealed on June 30, 2027. [13]
appropriations: There is appropriated out of the general revenues of the State of Hawaii the sum of $514,900 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_.HTM.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027. [13] These funds are for mental health, substance abuse treatment, and other services and equipment. [13] The appropriation also provides for the establishment of one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the women's court pilot program. [13]
assumptions_and_methodology: The women's court pilot program shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary and will be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13] The judiciary shall be responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [13] The program will implement trauma-informed and evidence-based practices and employ gender-responsive programming. [13]
agency_impact: There shall be established within the third circuit Kona division of the judiciary the women's court pilot program, which shall be under the supervision of the big island drug court. [13] The judiciary is responsible for providing mental health services under this pilot program. [13] This measure establishes one full-time equivalent (1.0 FTE) temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position for the pilot program. [13]
economic_impact: The goal of the program is diverting participants from incarceration, supporting their success in the community, and reducing recidivism. [13] Research reflects that for women, histories of abuse, trauma, poverty, mental illness, substance use disorders, and unhealthy relationships intersect with their entry into criminal behavior. [13] The services offered by the program are intended to address these areas, including trauma and mental health treatment, life-skills training, and housing support. [13] [13]
policy_impact: This measure permanently establishes the Women's Court Program in the First Circuit by codifying it within the Hawaii Revised Statutes. [14] It establishes a temporary two-year Women's Court Pilot Program within the Kona division of the Third Circuit, which sunsets on June 30, 2027. [13] [14] The judiciary is required to submit a report of its findings and recommendations on the pilot program to the governor and legislature prior to the 2026 and 2027 regular sessions. [13]

updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary update from the previous fiscal note is the inclusion of specific appropriation amounts, with the measure now appropriating $514,900 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2025-2026 and $557,000 (HB727_CD1_CCR58_.htm.txt) for fiscal year 2026-2027, replacing the prior version's unspecified sums. [14] The duration of the Women's Court Pilot Program in the Kona division of the Third Circuit was changed from three years to two years, with the sunset date moved to June 30, 2027. [14] [14] The number of temporary positions funded by the bill has been reduced from two to one, establishing only a temporary Kona drug court probation supervisor position. [14] The Judiciary is now explicitly required to be responsible for providing mental health services under the pilot program.
